subject: Libel and Slander
Wood and Wood Products
lead_paragraph: A jury awarded $5 million yesterday to a former Alabama football booster who claimed the N.C.A.A. defamed him when it imposed penalties on the Crimson Tide in 2002. The state court jury awarded the booster, Ray Keller, $3 million in punitive damages, $1 million for mental anguish, $500,000 for economic loss and $500,000 for damage to reputation.Keller, a timber dealer and fan whom the university severed ties with because of the investigation of the program, argued that the N.C.A.A. slandered and libeled him during the announcement of penalties by referring to him and others as “rogue boosters,” “parasites” and “pariahs.”Keller, who denied he did anything wrong, maintained that he was wrongly lumped in with other boosters who were accused of making improper contacts and payments to recruits in the 1990s.The N.C.A.A. did not use the name of Keller or other boosters in announcing penalties against Alabama, but their names appeared in news accounts and the university sent Keller a letter barring him from its athletics program.
